messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:08): kenneth, what is the frequency_
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:09): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee is alive
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:09): "It lives!"

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:12): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee, I'm wondering if you have been following the aria-syntax issue (aria-colon versus aria-dash) and if you can provide any insight on what the likelihood is of you guys changing your aria implementation in IE8
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:12): also wondering if you are going to be in the IE-team-chat thing tomorrow
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:13): and if you might be able to convince those in charge of that to try to make it more accessible to those who aren't actually running MS Windows as their OS
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:14): On the latter question, yes, I will be in the IE team chat, immediately following the HTML WG call (I'm presuming Dan is chairing one.)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:14): cool
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:14): on the followup question - is the web interface inaccessible on FF/Safari on MacOS?

eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:15): The question management of the software is incredibly helpful to those of us answering questions, so I'd rather not junk it and go, say, to just an IRC channel.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:15): dunno. will need to check again. I remember that last time I tried, the only way that it seemed to be accessible to me was through my Windows VM

eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:16): On the former question, no, I hadn't been following the aria discussion.  I don't know what the feasibility is of changing our implementation, but it's probably possible; IIRC, MS was amenable to colons to begin with in that discussion.

eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:17): in fact, I seem to recall personally saying it made a lot more sense as it was portable across schema, and having a few other people in the WG shout me down.  :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:18): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: if that is still the case, I hope you can be prepared to say as much in response to the TAG
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:19): Because I'm short of issues on which to appear on the opposite side of, say, our editor?  ;)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:21): well, also be prepared to explain how we could do it without risk of breaking existing content and/or to give other UA implementors an incentive to incur additional costs to change their text/html parsers to support it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:21): assuming that is is even practical

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:23): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: btw, remind me when it is that we can reasonably expect your implementation to actually support XHTML served as application/xhtml+xml (or other XML MIME type)?
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:23): wonders why a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 is putting eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee in the position of defending the aria: proposal
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:24): .. that is, to implement the existing mechanism we have for supporting namespaced content]
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:25): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: I'm clearly not doing that

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:25): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: As far as I'm aware, IE parses colonic attributes exactly the same as any other browser (i.e. the same as non-colonic attributes, just with a colon in its name), so it wouldn't be different for any other UA to support (where 'support' presumably means parsing in a namespacey way)
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:25): yes, you are, a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 . " also be prepared to explain  ..."
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:25): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: ...although actually I'm not sure you were implying it would be different for other UA implementors
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:26): snickers at "colonic"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:26): so there
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (21:26): ahh, it feels just like the mailing list in here.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:26): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: I'm not implying much of anything
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:27): it's 3am here where I am, and it could be imagined that I might possibly have a belly full of cheap gin
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (21:27): hopes that people realizes he's joking.
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:27): took it as ha-ha-only-serious
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:27): turned his attention to his other screen for a few, but is back.
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:27): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Ah, fair enough :-)
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: on XHTML: I'm not commenting on future feature requests for IE, as per policy.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:29): eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee: thanks - that's real helpful to us
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:29): my next question is about SVG
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:30): wonders if a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 is being sarcastic, but is prepared to believe the best. :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:30): i'm never sarcastic... ask anybody

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:31): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, friends don't let friends drink and chat. "remind me..." is clearly disingenuous; you know he has never said when they'd support it.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:31): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: thanks for the tip
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:31): Danc: worry not.  Mike and I are fine.  :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:32): . me reminds us all of who the real enemies are here... namely, Flash, Silverlight, etc.

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:33): I think we all share the common goal of trying to make sure that we have open standards for implementing all the features that we want to make available to Web developers

eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:33): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2:  Oh, no, I LOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOVE Silverlight.  Just ask anyone.  (I, on the other hand, can be quite sarcastic. Just ask anybody. :) )
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:34): agrees with Mike's last statement.
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (21:34): agrees with eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee's previous statement
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:34): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I don't want open standards - I just want things to work for me
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (21:34): s/previous/penultimate/
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:35): That usually seems to coincide with open standards, but my goal is purely selfish
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:35): fwiw, I watched a Silverlight presentation at XTech last week and was pretty impressed with what could be done with it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:36): the main lesson I took away was that we all need to get more motivated to get off our asses and provide a compelling alternative to that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:36): and to the other bad word
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:36): I made a shiny rotating monkey head with open standards
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:37): which is the kind of thing that compels at least me
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:37): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: that's a beautiful statement.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:37): Fl*sh
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:37): compelling alternative for working developers,I mean
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:37): other than "Do the right thing"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:40): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Was it accessible? :)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:41): to get in one more statement before I finally shut up (pass out): We shouldn't have as our goal to completely displace any of the existing alternative solutions to delivering content to users. What we should be trying to do at a minimum is to provide a *choices* to developers
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:42): ... a choice that doesn't require them to sign in blood in any particular vendor
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:43): s/blood in/blood with/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:44): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: some might say that accessibility is a mirage
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:45): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: you would never catch me saying that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:45): I was just speaking hypothetically
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:46): as I often do
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:46): Isn't that bordering on poetic in itself?
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:46): Ah, so 'a friend of yours' say accessibility is a mirage?

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:48): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: dunno. If you are venturing into "a friend of ours" vs. "a friend of mine" territory, I would like to remind you to carefully consider the oath you took when we made you a "made man"
eb8a98129bf103327310edbb5652fcee (21:48): wanders off to lunch...
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (21:48): goes off to find a power supply that doesn't switch itself off unless the cable is twisted precisely right
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (21:49): hopes a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 CCs a case of his cheap gin to the html-wg mailing list
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:49): considers actually going to sleep
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:50): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9: I would love to find a way to actually do that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:50): because I really think it might be one of the very few practical solutions
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (21:50): distributed inebriation
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (21:52): I think I prefer the sound of that over the other proposal
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:55): I think you might get into legal trouble, though :)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (21:56): Unless it's open-source gin
